Here's a few pointers:

-Debug every function as soon as you create it.  Fo=
r exampe, when 
you write mutate_add_node, apply it to some dummy genomes a=
nd make 
sure it really works.  Doing this will save you a lot of debugging=
 
time at the end, because if you only start debugging after the whole 
thi=
ng is created it will be very difficult to tease apart all the 
interlockin=
g parts to find what's causing a bug.

-Memory leaks can happen in C++ with=
 all the dynamic memory 
allocation (and cleanup) that NEAT requires so be =
careful.

-To test yout system when it's complete, use XOR.  It's not a ver=
y 
interesting experiment, but it usually catches major problems, like 
way=
 off parameterizations and things like that.  And it ensures that 
you can =
evolve structure since it requires a single hidden node to 
evolve.

ken

-=
